data values which isn‚Äôt understood by the machine. For
example, let a database maintained by a pet store, have an
entry with ‚Äòpet name‚Äô as ‚ÄòTim‚Äô with a ‚Äòdescription‚Äô as ‚ÄòThis is
a fun-loving, black coloured dog, which is 6 months old and
has not yet been vaccinated‚Äô. A natural language query asking
for the name of a ‚Äò6-month-old dog, dark in colour‚Äô would be
impossible to convert to the right SQL query, without
understanding the context.

Abstract‚ÄîThere has been an exponential growth in the
amount of data produced daily in recent years, owing to the
widespread use of technology. Ease of access to this data is of
utmost importance in this day and age. Although in the past, use
of structured query languages to query the data stored in the
hard-drive was satisfactory, use of natural language to access the
data is more desired. This paper talks about mapping partial
data values to its corresponding data values and attributes in the
schema to enrich the natural language query. Machine learning
algorithm, Long Short Term Memory, preceded by an
Embedding layer has been used on the HPCC Systems platform.
The resulting model gives an accuracy of 99.6%, while its
implementation with the experimental setup gives an accuracy
of 92%.

In this paper, a machine learning algorithm, Long Short
Term Memory, preceded by an Embedding layer has been
used, to map a partial data value to its corresponding data
value and attribute. The goal of the model is, given a string,
return the corresponding data value and attribute, if present in
the schema, otherwise return null. This model can hence be
used to enrich the natural language query and thereby aid in
the precise conversion of the natural language to SQL query.

Keywords‚ÄîPartial search, Long Short Term Memory, Natural
language query, Structured query language

I. INTRODUCTION

High-Performance Computing Cluster (HPCC), an open
source platform developed by LexisNexis Risk Solutions, has
been used to set up a cluster, distribute the data and perform
all the operations parallelly for a faster and a more effective
computation. HPCC Systems provide high-performance,
parallel processing and delivery for applications using big
data.

Data is any collection of information, in the form of text or
numbers, which has been translated into a format that can be
processed by a computer. Collection of data has revolutionized
almost every field in the recent past. Detection of cancerous
tumours, prediction of stocks, deciding which crop to be
grown on a given land and identifying fraud in credit card
transactions are some of the wonders that have been made
possible with the collection of data.

II. LITERATURE REVIEW
The concept of converting a natural language query to an
SQL query was first introduced in 1992, by Nikolaus Ott et al
[1] where natural language queries were mapped to an SQL+
language, an augmented SQL language.

With great importance being given to ‚Äòbig data‚Äô in this
millennial, the storage and the ease of access to this data
becomes crucial. One of the popular methods to store and
access data is the use of Structured Query Language (SQL).
SQL is a domain-specific programming language, designed to
manage structured data held in relational databases. SQL
provides multiple statements to query, manipulate and store
the data in a structured manner.

A concrete method for conversion was introduced by
Alessandra Giordani et al [2] in the year 2012. Linguistic
dependencies and meta-data were used to build sets of
WHERE and SELECT and combine them to form a set of SQL
queries. The right query was found to be within the first five
output queries 88% of the time.

Only professionals, having experience in this field could
access and manipulate big data. But now, with technology
decreasing the gap between individuals and data, an easier
access to this data is deemed necessary. Hence, models are
being built to make natural language an interface between
humans and the data stored in computers.

In 2014, Prasun Kanti Ghosh et al [3] explored the use of
morphological analysis, lexical analysis, syntactic analysis
and semantic analysis to generate an SQL query from a natural
language query. In the same year, K. Javubar et al [4] used
morphological, syntactic, semantic and pragmatic analysis

One of the main hurdles of converting a natural language
to an SQL query is that the natural language will have partial

978-1-7281-2619-7/19/$31.00 ¬©2019 IEEE

184

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

along with discourse integration to convert natural language to
SQL queries for semantic knowledge extraction from web
sources.
In 2018, Amit Pargut et al [5], used various Natural
Language Processing (NLP) techniques such as Tokenization,
Parts of Speech Tagging, Stemming and Lemmatization to get
the statement in the desired form to convert the natural
language query to a MySQL query. A decent accuracy of 82%
was achieved.
The Long Short Term Memory model used in this paper,
was introduced in 1997 by Sepp Hochreiter et al [6]. It is a
variant of Recurrent Neural Networks having an internal
memory cell in each node
One common area where all the above stated techniques
fail to convert a natural language query to an SQL query is
when, instead of the entire data value present in the schema is
to be mentioned in the natural language input, only a part of it
is mentioned or implied. The objective of this paper is to
provide a solution to this model by using a machine learning
algorithm to identify and solve such failure cases.

Figure 1.

Word Embeddings [7]

C. Long Short Term Memory
With the recent advancements in machine learning and data
science, it has been observed that Long Short Term Memory
(LSTM) algorithm is a powerful tool for sequence
classification.

III. CONCEPTS
A. Structured Query Language

LSTM is a variant of Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN).
RNN is an artificial neural network (ANN) where the output
of the current sample is a function of the current input and the
previous outputs. This enables the RNN to store/remember
the previous inputs, and hence is perceived to have memory.

Structured Query Language (SQL) is an ANSI/ISO
standard language for accessing and manipulating databases.
It is a domain-specific programming language and is designed
to manage structured data held in relational databases.

However, RNNs suffer from the problems of vanishing and
exploding gradient. Hence, LSTM was introduced to
compensate for the disabilities of RNNs.

SQL, although classified as a declarative language, has a
few procedural elements as well. Some of the features of SQL
are as follows.
1. Can create databases
2. Can insert, update and delete records in
databases
3. Can execute queries against databases
4. Can retrieve required data from databases
5. Can create stored procedures

In LSTM, a memory is included. The cell has the current
memory of the node which can be written into, read and
erased just like a computer memory, with the only difference
being that this cell is analogous.

B. Embedding Layer
A word embedding is a class of approaches for representing
words using a dense vector representation. The use of an
embedding layer is an improvement over the na√Øve way of
encoding the unique words present in the vocabulary into
large vectors.
In an embedding, words are represented by dense vectors
where a vector represents the projection of the word into a
continuous vector space. The positions of the vectors for
each word is learnt based on its surrounding words in the
given corpus.
The use of embedding layer before the LSTM model
hence gives context to the input samples. This can be clearly
seen in figure 1, where the male-female relationship, and the
verb tense relationships have been recognized while
projecting the words.

Figure 2.

185

Long Short Term Memory [8]

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

As seen in Figure 1, LSTM essentially has two inputs. X t,
which is the current input and h t-1, which is the previous
output and one output h t. The memory cell is controlled by
the forget valve (gate) and new memory valve (gate).

V. DATASET EXTRACTION
The major hurdle faced while training a machine learning
model for this problem statement is the unavailability of a
suitable dataset. To overcome this, a dataset is created based
on the given schema.

Forget gate is a neural network with the sigmoid activation
function which is multiplied with the previous memory to
decide how much of the previous memory is to be
remembered. New memory gate is a neural network which is
similar to the forget gate except this decides wo what extent
the new memory should influence the old memory.

The schema along with the markers for columns which
need a partial search (ex: Description, Experience etc) is taken
as an input. The marked columns of the schema are then
converted to a CSV file using the Apache Common CSV
library. This is used as a dataset for the algorithm.

The new memory itself is calculated by a third neural
network, which is followed by a ‚Äòtanh‚Äô activation function.
The output of this neural network is element wise multiplied
with the new memory gate‚Äôs output and added to the output
of the element wise product of the forget gate and the old
memory.

VI. PRE-PROCESSING
A. Obtaining unique values and reconstruction of dataset
The data extracted is a set of columns of the input schema.
To format this into a dataset, the first step is to obtain the
unique values of each column (which forms the temporary
feature matrix) and the target value for each sample shall be
the data value and the corresponding attribute (column name)
separated by a place-holder value. This is done in order to
avoid an expensive search after prediction to determine the
attribute the partial data value belongs to.

Finally, to generate the output of the LSTM node, a fourth
neural network is used to determine how much the new
memory should influence the output and is multiplied with
the tanh activation of the new memory to generate the output.
IV. PLATFORM USED

B. Tokenization of dataset
The machine learning algorithm being used takes integers
as inputs. Therefore, the strings in the feature matrix are split
into words, and each word in the entire dataset is assigned a
unique integer. The training samples now contain variable
number of integers.

LexisNexis, an industry leader in data content, data
aggregation, and information services independently
developed and implemented a solution for data-intensive
computing called HPCC Systems (High-Performance
Computing Cluster) Systems.

C. Label Encoding and One-hot encoding
The target vector still consists of strings having the data
value and its corresponding attribute appended to it. A label
encoder is first used to converting these strings into unique
integer labels. The labels are then one hot encoded, i.e. each
integer value is represented as a binary vector.
This format is more suitable to input to the Long Short
Term memory mode.

Figure 3.

D.Random sampling
Iterating through each sample, we randomly choose a
variable number of tokens/integers (the range of which is
calculated based on the length of the sample) for a fixed
number of times (based on the number of samples) and
appended to the dataset along with its target value. Note,
while randomly chosen tokens must be in the same order as
seen in the original sample.

Cluster [9].

HPCC Systems platform utilizes commodity clusters of
hardware running the Linux operating system similar to the
cluster depicted in Figure 2. Custom system software and
middleware components were developed and layered on the
base Linux operating system to provide the execution
environment and distributed filesystem support required for
data-intensive computing.

E. Padding and truncation
Since each sample now contains variable number of
tokens, it is padded with trailing zeros. The length of each
sample is then truncated to the 75th quartile of the lengths.
This is done to ensure that all samples have a fixed number of
features/tokens without much of it being the padded zeros.

As there was a need for a new computing paradigm to
address the growing volumes of data, the design approach of
HPCC Systems also includes the definition of a new highlevel language for parallel data processing called ECL
(Enterprise Data Control Language).

All these steps have been summarized in Figure 4

186

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

Figure 4.

Pre-Processing

VII.

SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE

Figure 5 shows the system architecture. The dataset is
first extracted from the input schema as mentioned in
section V. The dataset is then transformed into a suitable
format and pre-processed as mentioned in section VI.
Figure 5. System Architecture

The dataset is then randomly split into training and test
data (a low train-test split ratio is recommended).
IX.

The training data is given as the input to the embedding
layer to learn and project the words into a suitable vector
space. This is followed by an LSTM model and an output
dense layer.

RESULTS

The dataset used is the ‚ÄòDescription‚Äô column of the
database described in the previous section. It has over 60,000
data values, each being a string of sentences describing a
product. The model gives a test accuracy of 99.6%. That is,
given a partial data value (description), it is mapped to the
right data value 99.6% of the time.
To demonstrate the integration of this model and its usage,
the algorithm discussed in this paper was integrated with a
natural language to SQL query conversion model built for
this purpose. 50 input queries were formulated which tested
the partial searching capability of the model. Out of the 50,
46 queries were correctly mapped to the correct data value,
attribute and hence, SQL query. Table 1 shows some of the
input queries and its output.

Predictions are made on the test data and then an
evaluation is done. Hyper-tuning is then done by fine tuning
the parameters of the model for better results.
EXPERIMENTAL SETUP
VIII.
The proposed system is implemented on the database
whose schema is shown in figure (2). The database contains 6
tables. The database contains data of customers, the products
they have bought and the sales details of each product. The
tables ‚Äòt_cstmrs‚Äô contains data of customer, ‚Äòt_prds‚Äô contains
product data, ‚Äòt_saldtls‚Äô contains sales data, ‚Äòt_ggrphy‚Äô
contains the geographical location of the customers, ‚Äòt_prdcat‚Äô
contains data of product-category and ‚Äòt_prdsubcat‚Äô contains
data of product-subcategory. The descriptive column present
in our database is the ‚ÄòDescription‚Äô column in ‚Äòt_prds‚Äô table
which contains description of the products.

X.

CONCLUSION

Use of Embedding layer helps understand the context and
hence infer the meaning of the input and map it to its implied
data value. The Long Short Term Memory model identifies
the patterns in the series of words in the dataset and can
hence successfully map the input strings to the correct data
values if present. Hence the model gives outstanding results,
can understand the context as well as the patterns in the
specified columns.

EDVHGVLPLODULW\PRGHOVWRLPSURYHWKHUHVXOWVIURPWKH2&5

$EVWUDFW¬≤With thousands of books across hundreds of
disciplines present in a library, manual allocation of books is
both time consuming, human intensive, as well as inefficient in
terms of monetary costs. The presence of manual labour while
providing employment to a section of society tends to slow down
the process of lending in addition to increasing the probability
of errors. The proposed research work attempts at automating
the library book management system there by reducing latency
and long queues as well as the potential of making mistakes in
the distribution of books. Recent advancements of deep neural
networks have improved textual recognition in natural scenes.
The system proposed employs a neural network model for text
detection and recognition, having the potential to reduce and
even eliminate manual labour performed by the staff. This
paper attempts to investigate neural networks for the
application of library management by proposing our own
Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and text matching
algorithms. This task further introduces challenges such as
getting the exact name of the book as well as dealing with
distorted images and varied backgrounds. The system thus
developed performs very well with book covers producing
results over 60% in accuracy against current models that
provide about 40% thereby making the system achieve state of
the art performance on book cover information retrieval.

Keywords‚ÄîLibrary
Management,
Optical
Character
Recognition, textual Matching, Face Recognition, imageprocessing, scene text detection.

516,167,787(2)7(&+12/2*<
%DQJDORUH,QGLD
NULVKQD#JPDLOFRP
Abstract‚Äî In this paper, we propose to explain the
application of automated ground vehicles as delivery robots.
This system is developed and designed with the intended
application being delivery of items within large campuses
and buildings. The system proposed in this paper uses
Google maps and direction API for getting the navigation
data, but the same can be implemented without using third
party application if the map of the intended area of usage is
available. Donkey and carrot algorithm has been developed
and used for navigation using the data obtained from the
used API. To get the data on to the unmanned ground
vehicle, a server is set up on the onboard microcontroller
which gets the data from the cloud, on which further
processing is done.

embedded systems, self-driving, UGV

199

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

IdentiÔ¨Åcation of Criminal Activity Hotspots using
Machine Learning to Aid in Effective Utilization of
Police Patrolling in Cities with High Crime Rates
Ramshankar Yadhunath1 , Srivenkata Srikanth2 , Arvind Sudheer3 , Suja Palaniswamy4*
Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering
Amrita School of Engineering, Bengaluru
Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham
India - 560 035
1
2
yadramshankar@gmail.com; srikanthtk99@gmail.com; 3 arvind.sudheer@gmail.com;

Abstract‚ÄîCriminal activity has always been a major deterrent
in human progress and the constant presence of criminal activitiesstemmingoutofmultifariouscauseshasbeenahindrancefor
human sustainable living. The problem further aggravates when
thereisadearthofpoliceforcetopreventcrime.Incountrieslike
India where the police to population ratio is much less than the
United Nations‚Äô Standard, the need of the hour is to efficiently
utilize the existing force to prevent crimes. In this paper, we
propose a solution that would facilitate effective distribution of
police forces in a city among multiple districts based on the
extent to which each district is prone to crime at a given hour,
in a given day, for a given month. We have used the Chicago
Crime Dataset in this work. The problem has been modelled
as an imbalanced classification p  roblem a  nd s  upervised
machine learning algorithms such as Logistic Regression, Naive
Bayes, K Nearest Neighbours, Support Vector Machines,
Decision Trees,Random Forests, Gradient Boosting Trees have
been employedand their performances have been evaluated. In
particular, the Gradient Boosting Tree has achieved the best
performanceinourcase.
Index Terms‚ÄîCrime Hotspots, Police Force Optimization,
Supervised Machine Learning, Multi-class Classification, Class
Imbalance

I. INTRODUCTION
Ashumansocietyisprogressingtowardsmoresophisticated
methods of improving life standards, it is still not in a very
able state to protect its community from the detrimental
effectsofcriminalactivities.AccordingtotheUnitedNations‚Äô
2030 agenda for sustainable development, ‚ÄúThere can be no
sustainable development without peace and no peace without
sustainable development‚Äù [1]. This statement is in itself a
complete summary of how important it is in today‚Äôs world
to prevent crime and promote peace. Crime can be as small
as a roadside theft or as dangerous as a homicide, and
very often most crimes arise from multiple causes such as
a troubled childhood, influenceof delinquentpeers,poverty,
unemployment, drug abuse etc. [2].
The depictions in [3] encompasses research that affirmsa
declineincrimewithanincreaseinpoliceforce.However,in
countries like India with a much lower police to population

4*

p suja@blr.amrita.edu

ratio than the United Nations‚Äô standard [4], it is of greater use
to identify methods to effectively distribute police force among
districts based on each district‚Äôs susceptibility to be affected
by crime. The regions that have high chances of vulnerability
to crimes can be termed as ‚ÄúCrime Hotspots‚Äù [5].
The main goal of this work is inclined towards using data
science as a means of promoting social good by providing a
methodology to alleviate the effect of crime. This is done by
laying foundations to a system that would help the police force
to judiciously distribute their resources among regions based
on the individual regions‚Äô chances of being prone to crime on a
particular day, in a particular month, at a particular hour. We
have used a variant of the OSEMN(Obtain, Scrub, Explore,
Model, Interpret) framework [6] in order to perform accurate
data analysis and create efÔ¨Åcient models of computation. The
entire code for this research is written in python and the
pandas, seaborn, sklearn packages have been used extensively
for obtaining results.
In the remainder of this paper, Section II discusses related
work in the domain, Section III describes the problem in
consideration, Section IV delineates the methodology used,
Section V unearths the Ô¨Åndings and results and Ô¨Ånally Section
VI summarizes the work and emphasises its scope in Indian
context.
II. R ELATED W ORK
The use of computer science as a discipline in unearthing
patterns in crime has been explored many times before and has
resulted in signiÔ¨Åcant amount of work being performed on the
same. While works such as that by Ashokan et. al. [7] focus
on a speciÔ¨Åc type of crime, several other works concentrate on
crime as a singular entity. Data sets such as the Chicago crime
data set(used in our work) are well maintained and updated
frequently, providing researchers access to data that can help
deÔ¨Åne and solve pervasive problems related to maintaining
peace and order.
Sathyadevan et. al. [8] collected data related to crime from
sources such as the web, social media and news sites to gener-

¬ã,(((

200

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

ate an unstructured dataset, and analysis was performed using
MongoDB as a database. Supervised and apriori algorithms
were used to predict regions with high crime probability.
Almanie et. al. [9] performed extensive exploratory data
analysis to unearth patterns of two different crime datasets of
both Denver and Los Angeles. Apriori algorithms were later
used to predict future crime locations. The varied nature of
these predictions on either dataset were discussed. Das et. al.
[10] discussed the geo-statistical spatial clustering technique
to identify criminal hotspots in the context of Indian crime
data. The paper performed forecasting techniques to predict
crime hotspots for the next year given past data. Yu et. al.
[11] performed the task of crime hotspot mapping with special
focus to bruglary. The paper used machine learning algorithms
and deep learning approaches on different training samples
to converge to a best possible solution, with neural network
giving the best possible accuracy of about 88%. Shekhar et. al.
[12] produced an interesting spatio-temporal analysis of crime
and provided basis for an approach to using crime data to
mitigate the effects of crime in the indian context. The paper
based its work on Kolar, a small town in the Indian state of
Karnataka and identiÔ¨Åed criminal activity in the town using
geo-spatial mapping.
But in the end, the dichotomy of most crime related data
mining works performed classify the computed results into two
classes which indicate whether a particular crime is going to
occur or not. Even though a few applications manage to get
this done with satisfactory accuracies, minimal work has been
done in classifying the hotspots into multiple classes based on
the odds of occurrence of crimes at a particular hotspot given
a particular space in time.
Our work aims at performing such a division into multiple
classes and will help prioritize the hotspots and aid in judicious
distribution and use of staff which is of utmost concern in a
country like India where the police force is much less than
sufÔ¨Åcient. In a nutshell, our work aims to greatly help out the
precincts with shortage of working staff.
III. P ROBLEM D ESCRIPTION
The scope of this work is to analyze crime data and identify
crime hotspots or regions of heightened criminal activity in a
given month, on a given day, at a given hour. The original
dataset used in this paper is the Chicago Crime Dataset
presented in the City of Chicago Data Portal [13]. The dataset
consists of all crime records in the city of Chicago from 2001
to present. The dataset is updated on a daily basis. In this work,
we have used the data from the years 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018
and 2019 (records till 05/05/19). We describe methods to preprocess the data, compress it to reshape the dataset into a better
suited form for our analysis, prepare the training and test data
explicitly and Ô¨Ånally we train machine learning algorithms
to classify entries as crime hotspots based on the intensity
of crimes in those regions in the past during a speciÔ¨Åc time
point. A time point according to our work is a one-dimensional
vector that is organized of the values of month, day and hour
(1). Our proposed algorithms use these time points to classify

Fig. 1. OSEMN variant methodology

each of the districts in the dataset as low crime rate, medium
crime rate or high crime rate areas for each speciÔ¨Åc time point.
‚Üí
‚àí
t = [month day hour]
(1)
The problem is essentially a supervised multi-class classiÔ¨Åcation problem having class imbalance [14]. The next section
will shed some light on the implementation details and the
theory behind our work.
IV. M ETHODOLOGY
In this work, we have employed a data science process that
closely derives from the OSEMN framework as followed in
[15] in order to beget the best possible analysis and results
from the data. The OSEMN framework is a popular data
science process that follows the step-wise methodology of
Obtain, Scrub, Explore, Model and Interpret. We have used
the Obtain, Scrub, Explore and Model aspects of OSEMN as
in Fig. 1.
A. Obtain Data
The original training dataset for our project has been obtained from the City of Chicago Data Portal and consists of
11,46,382 entries and 22 features. The main features are Date,
Block, Primary Type, Location, Arrest, District and Year. Out
of the 22 features, 2 are of boolean, 7 are of Ô¨Çoat, 3 are of
integer and 10 are of string data types. This dataset contains
the records of all the crimes that were reported as Ô¨Årst-hand
accounts in Chicago from 2015 to 2019 (till May). Apart from
this, data from 2012 to 2014 were used to create one of the
testing samples.
B. Scrub Data
This section has further been divided into subsections for
ease of understanding.
a) Getting rid of missing values: Missing values in a
dataset is a common factor leading to poor model performance.
As we had a relatively clean dataset, there were not too many
missing values in concern. The missing information accounted
for only a small portion of the complete data and therefore,
entries with missing data were removed and 98.55% of the
data was retained.

201

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

b) Feature Engineering: First it was important to
process the ‚ÄúDate‚Äù feature into a form suitable for writing
python code. After this processing, we feature engineered [16]
the separate features of ‚ÄúM onth‚Äù, ‚ÄúDay‚Äù and ‚ÄúHour‚Äù, since
the ‚ÄúDate‚Äù feature in our original dataset was a combination
of the month of the crime, the day of the crime and the time
of the crime. This was achieved by using the apply() function
of the pandas package [17] and python‚Äôs datetime module [18].
data[Date] ‚Üê changeT oDatetime(data[Date])
data[M onth] ‚Üê data[Date].extractM onth()
data[Day] ‚Üê data[Date].extractDay()
data[Hour] ‚Üê data[Date].extractHour()
c) Compressing the dataset: The dataset was then
compressed and reshaped into a new dataset. This new dataset
has been named as crimeDat in all further discussions in this
work. crimeDat was the Ô¨Ånal dataset that was used in our
work. Following is the pseudocode for creating crimeDat.
In the code, data is our dataset before compression and
reshaping.
cols ‚Üê [M onth, Day, District, Hour]
crimeDat ‚Üê data.groupby(cols)
crimeDat ‚Üê crimeDat.aggregateByCrimeCount()
crimeDat ‚Üê crimeDat.descSort(by = District )

Fig. 2. Distribution of Crimes

within 0.75 standard deviations of the mean of the distribution,
crimeDat[Alarm] got 1(Medium alarm). Anything less than
these were classiÔ¨Åed as 0(Low alarm) and anything more
than these were classiÔ¨Åed as 2(High alarm). The following
pseudocode describes how the target labels are set.

if crimeDat[CrimeCount] ‚â§ 14 then
crimeDat[Alarm] ‚Üê 0
end if
if crimeDat[CrimeCount] ‚â• 15 and ‚â§ 33 then
crimeDat[Alarm] ‚Üê 1
end if
if crimeDat[CrimeCount] ‚â• 34 then
crimeDat[Alarm] ‚Üê 2
end if

At this point, crimeDat has 44,361 entries and 5 features
(M onth, Day, District, Hour, CrimeCount). The Ô¨Årst 5
entries of crimeDat are given in Table I.
C. Explore
A new target feature crimeDat[Alarm] was then
engineered for the crimeDat dataset . The target feature had
the values 0, 1 or 2 based on the alarm rate of a particular
entry.
Labelling a particular entry as 0(Low alarm), 1(Medium
alarm) or 2(High alarm) is a process that would be subjectively
different from approach to approach. In our approach, we have
plotted a histogram as in Fig. 2 that shows the distribution
of the values in crimeDat[CrimeCount]. The distribution
bears a close resemblance to the normal distribution. We used
this distribution to come up with an intuitive classiÔ¨Åcation of
entries that are within crimeDat. We classiÔ¨Åed all entries
such that for values in crimeDat[CrimeCount] that occur

Fig. 3 describes the correlation matrix [19] between the
features in crimeDat and the following conclusions can be
drawn of it :
‚Ä¢ Almost all the features have no correlation with each
other. This is good as certain machine learning algorithms
are affected adversely by multi-collinearity.
‚Ä¢ The feature Hour has the greatest positive correlation
with the target feature Alarm.
Fig. 4 describes the class imbalance involved in our problem. A class imbalance occurs in a classiÔ¨Åcation algorithm
when the number of samples of each class type is signiÔ¨Åcantly
different for each class. In our problem, the number of
samples classiÔ¨Åed as ‚Äúmedium‚Äù(crimeDat[Alarm]=1) is way
more than those classiÔ¨Åed as ‚Äúlow‚Äù(crimeDat[Alarm]=0)
and ‚Äúhigh‚Äù(crimeDat[Alarm]=2). Datasets with class imbalance are usually more complex to make accurate classiÔ¨Åcations
and often lead to the ‚ÄúAccuracy Paradox‚Äù [20].
D. Model
With the creation of the crimeDat dataset for classiÔ¨Åcation,
the next task is to use this dataset to make our classiÔ¨Åcations.

202

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

the independent features of crimeDat. Now, let algo be the
machine learning algorithm applied to our dataset. Also, let a
be a possible value for the crimeDat[Alarm].
‚Üí
‚àí
ti + d algo = a
(5)
‚Üí
‚àí
If we keep algo and ti constant, we can afÔ¨Årm that a is
dependent on d. Therefore, it is inferred that a (Alarm Rate)
‚Üí
‚àí
at a given time point ti is dependent on d or the district in
question. Therefore, not all districts need the same amount of
police force for patrolling at a given time point. The next step
embodied the use machine learning algorithms to effectively
classify [21] a particular district according to its vulnerability
to crime at a particular time point. The scope of the work
discussed here, deal with machine learning algorithms such
as Gradient Boosting Tree(GBT) [22], Random Forest(RF)
[23], Decision Tree(DT) [24], K Nearest Neighbour(knn) [25],
Support Vector Machine(SVM) [26], Logistic Regression(LR)
[27] and Naive Bayes(NB) [28]. It was observed that tree
based algorithms gave signiÔ¨Åcant leverage over non-tree based
models owing to the imbalanced nature of the dataset.

V. E XPERIMENTAL R ESULTS
The most important aspect of a machine learning problem is
evaluating a model‚Äôs performance. In accordance to the ‚ÄúNo
Free Lunch‚Äù theorem [29], having to compare multiple ML
models over several parameters or evaluation metrics is an
inevitable process. In our supervised classiÔ¨Åcation problem,
the metrics used were accuracy, precision, recall f1 score and
unweighted average recall (UAR) to evaluate model performance [30].

or region in question‚Äù. The proof is as follows :

In (6), (7), (8), (9) and (10), the terms that have been used
have the meanings as follows :
‚Ä¢ T P : True Positives (It refers to the number of positive
samples that have been correctly identiÔ¨Åed as positive)
‚Ä¢ F P : False Positives (It refers to the number of negative
samples that have been incorrectly identiÔ¨Åed as positive)
‚Ä¢ T N : True Negatives (It refers to the number of negative
samples that have been correctly identiÔ¨Åed as negative)
‚Ä¢ F N : False Negatives (It refers to the number of positive
samples that have been incorrectly identiÔ¨Åed as negative)

Here, A is the ‚ÄúAlarm‚Äù vector or our target feature here and
D represents the ‚ÄúDistrict‚Äù vector(that is inclusive of the 31
districts in Chicago).
From (3), we can formulate (4) as follows
‚Üí

(4)
for d ‚àà D The signiÔ¨Åcance of (4) is that it represents how
a ‚ÄúTime point vector‚Äù and d (district) together encompasses

203

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)
‚Ä¢

‚Ä¢

‚Ä¢

‚Ä¢

‚Ä¢

P recision : Describes the likeliness of a sample being
in class X if it has been predicted as belonging to class
X
Recall : Describes the likeliness of the model to correctly
classify a sample as belonging to class X if it actually
belongs to class X
F 1 : It is a measure that describes a relation between
P recision and Recall. Higher the F1 score for a class,
the better the model performs in classifying that particular
class.
U AR : Unweighted Average Recall (It is the average of
the individual recall values of each class that is to be
classiÔ¨Åed)
Ri : Recall value for ith class

The models have been trained on 75% of the crimeDat
dataset and then tested across 3 different samples of data.
‚Ä¢ Sample 1 : 25% of crimeDat (With class imbalance)
‚Ä¢ Sample 2 : 25% of crimeDat (Without class imbalance
- Achieved by oversampling)
‚Ä¢ Sample 3 : All crime records from years 2012 to 2014

The results were achieved by using k=5 for KNN, ‚Äúmultinomial‚Äù logistic regression for LR, ‚Äúlinear‚Äù kernel for SVM,
gaussian NB and 1000 trees for both RF and GBT algorithms.
From Table II,it is evident that the best performing model
is different for all the 3 samples taken for testing. Apart
from the accuracies, Table II also highlights the F1 scores
and the UARs of each model. The averaging method for F1
scores across all the models is macroaveraging. This is done
so because macroaveraging provides a sense of the model‚Äôs
effectiveness on the minor classes in the dataset [31]. In this
case, the minor samples are those classiÔ¨Åed as ‚Äúhigh alarm‚Äù
and it is more important that these high alarm regions are well
classiÔ¨Åed in order to maintain citizen safety. The GBT has the
highest accuracy in sample 1, while the random forest tree(RF)
tops sample 2. The KNN ranks highest in accuracy in sample
3. However, since our dataset is imbalanced, using accuracy
as the only metric to make a valid conclusion on model
performance is not conclusive. Therefore, the macroaveraged
F1 scores and UARs have been taken into consideration. The
highest F1 scores across sample 1, sample 2 and sample 3 are
obtained by GBT, RF and knn respectively, again. The higher
macroaveraged F1 scores indicates that the given model is able
to recognize the presence of minority classes in the dataset and
also classify them reasonably. Higher values of UARs indicates
the ability of a model to identify samples as belonging to their
particular classes. On comparison across the UAR metric, it is
observed that GBT, RF and GBT perform best across samples
1,2 and 3 respectively. Therefore, it can be afÔ¨Årmed that the
top 3 models in this research are GBT, RF and knn. The
worst performance is obtained from Support Vector Machines
(SVM) as the UAR score for SVM is null. This is so because
the SVM model did not recognize the presence of the ‚Äúhigh
alarm‚Äù minority class and did not make any such predictions.

This is a very dangerous situation as any model aimed at
answering the questions within the scope of this work should
be able to predict high crime regions in order to aid in keeping
citizens safe. A more dangerous situation that can arise is when
regions that have a high alarm rate (crimDat[Alarm] = 2) are
classiÔ¨Åed as regions with low crime rate (crimDat[Alarm]
= 0). Such a misclassiÔ¨Åcation would lead to much less
police force being deployed in a district that requires much
more force to curb the crime rate at a given time. Regions
with high crime rate (crimDat[Alarm] = 2) being classiÔ¨Åed
as moderately alarming regions (crimDat[Alarm] = 1) is
a comparatively less dangerous misclassiÔ¨Åcation. Therefore,
this research also tries to Ô¨Ånd models that will reduce the
percentage of misclassiÔ¨Åcations of ‚Äúhigh alarm‚Äù regions as
‚Äúlow alarm‚Äù regions. Table III summarizes the percentages of
samples that are 2, but wrongly classiÔ¨Åed as 0. As observed,
GBT performs amazingly well across all 3 samples with very
low misclassiÔ¨Åcation percentages of 0.04%, 0.02% and 0%.
It is therefore necessary to use a computing model for our
deÔ¨Åned problem that is able to
‚Ä¢ Achieve a high accuracy among all the 3 classes (low,
medium and high)
‚Ä¢ Achieve a high macroaveraged F1 score to showcase
better precision-recall relation and thus achieve the ability
to identify all three classes without any bias.
‚Ä¢ Obtain a low percentage of samples that are ‚Äúhigh alarm‚Äù
regions , but wrongly classiÔ¨Åed as ‚Äúlow alarm‚Äù regions.
The GBT achieves all the above points with much more
effectiveness as compared to the other models used in this
work.
VI. C ONCLUSION
Prevention of criminal activity is among the top most
priorities of the world in the building of a well connected,
halcyon community where people are protected from all kinds
of mental and physical harm. This paper provides a means
of preventing crime by providing a possible solution to the
common problem of ‚Äúlack of police force‚Äù in regions with
regular criminal activity. This paper provides a new outlook
in the way how crime related data has been explored in the
research world by proposing a way to judiciously use existing
police force to alleviate the impact of crime. The methodology
delineated in the paper gives an example of how the quantity of
police force needed at a particular district is directly dependent
on the instance of time as criminal unrest varies from district to
district with respect to a particular time point. The dataset used
in our research is a record of the crimes that have occurred in
Chicago. However, the presence of publicly available crime
data(of similar features) of the crimes in India could help
implement the solution proposed in the paper in the Indian
context. This would be of huge help to the Indian police system
as it would enable in the judicious usage of existing resources
to tackle crime, especially as India has a seemingly large
deÔ¨Åcit of police force to tackle the country‚Äôs crime related
issues. The use of machine learning techniques provides yet
another deep insight into the Ô¨Åeld and offers yet another

RYHUYLHZRIGDWDPDQDJHPHQWDQGSXEOLVKLQJ

Abstract‚Äî Privacy has become a prime importance in this
digital era. Personally Identifiable Information (PII) gets
collected in various firms such as educational institutions,
government organizations, hospitals etc.. The collected data is
often published and utilized for the purpose of analysis,
research, decision making, advertisement or for the purpose of
business. It is the duty of the data curator to store and to publish
the data safely. A person who is having accessibility to the data
that is published must not be able to identify or learn any new
personal or sensitive information of an individual. Statistical
Disclosure Control(SDC) is a suite of anonymization techniques.
The aim of SDC is post processing the data containing sensitive
or personal information and effectively protect the privacy of
the participating data subject. However these techniques leads
to ‚Äúinformation loss ‚Äú, i.e., any analysis or research carried on
such a data might not give a appropriate result. This paper aims
to discuss various metrics available to assess the information loss
in the processed data and an attempt has been made to propose
our technique for measuring the loss.
Keywords‚Äî Anonymization, Information Loss, Privacy
Preserving Data Publishing, Loss Metric, Identity Disclosure, PII,
Utility, SDC.

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

Plant Diseases Detection and Classification using
Machine Learning Models
Poojan Panchal
School of Computer Science and
Engineering
Dr. Vishwanath Karad MIT World Peace
University, Pune
pdavpoojan@gmail.com

Vignesh Charan Raman
School of Computer Science and
Engineering
Dr. Vishwanath Karad MIT World Peace
University, Pune
vigneshcharan26@gmail.com

where color code modification & Boolean operation is applied
to the binary mask of each pixel of the leaf image[7]. He
suggested the technique for identifying plant leaf illness in
which H histograms and color channels are altered [8-9] Pang
et al suggested the technique for computerized assessment of
crop leaf disease pictures by incorporating local limit and
increasing seed area [10]. Distinct intelligent systems have
been developed to diagnose corn plant for computerized
identification of corn diseases [11-12]. While high
competence is achieved by the deep learning tactics, it
generally generates a model of big size. In addition, studies
involving traditional machine learning methods are generally
complicated or based on outdated feature extraction [13-16],
and costly camera photography is required[17].

Abstract‚ÄîIn the agricultural sector, identification of plant
diseases is extremely crucial as they hamper robustness and
health of the plant which play a vital role in agricultural
productivity. These problems are common in plants, if proper
prevention methods are not taken it might seriously affect the
cultivation. The current method of detecting disease is done by
an expert's opinion and physical analysis, which is timeconsuming and costly in the real world. Hence, computer-based
detection has become a necessity. This paper comprises of an
overview of image segmentation using K-means clustering and
HSV dependent classification for recognizing infected part of
the leaf and feature extraction using GLCM. The efficiency of
the proposed methodology is able to detect and classify the plant
diseases successfully with an accuracy of 98% when processed
by Random Forest classifier.

The above experimental studies shows that there are
various automated processes available to identify plant
diseases using classifiers like SVM and Naive Bayes, but the
proposed approach uses HSV value alteration technique for
fully automated image segmentation process and Random
Forest for Image classification which is less cumbersome,
easy to apply and has enhanced the accuracy.

Keywords‚Äî Hue Saturation Value, K-Means, Gray Level Cooccurrence Matrix, Classification

I. INTRODUCTION
Agriculture is the backbone of the economy in various
countries. The agricultural productivity is dependent on
various factors. Advancement in agricultural sector is two to
four times more effective in raising the revenue among the
poorest people compared to any other sectors. If proper
identification and prevention methods are not followed in
early stage of cultivation, it can lead to crop failure and
downfall of the economy in any country. For accurate advice
on plant diseases, finding farm specialists in rural areas is a
very difficult task[1]. This needs continuous monitoring of
specialists, however, which in big farms could be exorbitantly
costly and time consuming [2]. Due to these challenges faced
by farmers, Image processing techniques can provide insights
into recognition and treatment of plant disease at early stages
before spreading [3]. In most cases disease symptoms are seen
on the leaves, fruit and stem. the leaf is considered for plant
disease detection. This paper throws light on various
techniques used for image segmentation and classification of
plant diseases.
II.

Shamla Mantri
School of Computer Science and
Engineering
Dr. Vishwanath Karad MIT World Peace
University, Pune
shamla.mantri@mitwpu.edu.in

III.

PROPOSED METHOD

The proposed methodology contains five major steps that
are represented in Fig-1

Fig. 1. Proposed methodolgy for plant disease detection

A. Image aquisition
Pictures of different leaves are photographed using a
camera or comparative gadgets. Leaves affected with diseases
such as Bacterial Spot, Early Blight, Late blight are used in
the dataset. Size and resolution of the images play a crucial
role in the efficiency of the proposed methodology.

LITERATURE REVIEW

In [2], The approach developed over image processing is
quick and efficient for grading of plant diseases. Otsu method
was used for segmentation of leaf image [4-6]. The disease
spot area is then segmented by the Sobel operator for edge
detection. In final step, infected area is recognized by
calculating the quotient of diseased spot. K-mean is then used
to cluster grape leaf diseases and through next step infected
part is identified using Neural Networks, the diseased part is
recognized.

B. Image Processing
The required image was obtained by transforming the
original image (i.e. the image size has been converted to
256X256 pixels). Unwanted noise from the image is removed.
The BGR format is converted to gray scale as well as HSV

Barbedo et. Al. provided an automatic strategy to the
segmentation of illness symptoms in digital plant leaf
pictures

¬ã,(((
211

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

format for applying the proposed method. Smoothening of
image is also done using smoothing filter.
C. Image Segmentation
The segmentation of images is the method of splitting a
picture into several components or sections. The foreground is
isolated from the background or densely packed areas of
pixels, depending on color or shape similarities. In the
proposed method image segmentation is done using either KMean clustering or using HSV value Alteration. Both of these
approaches lead to equivalent results.
1) K-Means: The K-means clustering algorithm
performs segmentation by minimizing the sum of squares of
distances between the image intensities and the cluster
centroids. In the present work, K-means clustering is used for
segmenting an image into diseased part and healthy part.
Initially each pixel is considered as a cluster, then the distance
between two nearby clusters are minimized by combining
them [18-19]. This process is repeated unless different color
K number of clusters are formed, this helps to differentiate
diseased part of the leaf.

Fig. 2. Hue Saturation Value conical representation

‚àí

=

2) Hue Saturation Value Alteration: When BGR image
is converted to HSV format it contains 3 elements known as
H-Hue corresponds to the value component (Base pigment)
hence just by selecting a range of Hue, any color can be
selected.(0 to 360), S-Saturation is the amount of color (depth
of pigment) ranges from 0-100% and V- value is basically the
brightness of color (0-100%). Fig-2 explains the
representation of HSV format. The RBG format can be
converted to HSV using (1-7). All the leaves have colors in
green range hence HSV upper value and lower value
identification is done only once as depicted in Fig-3(a). Lower
boundaries of HSV are 0,61,68 respectively and upper
boundaries are 30,255,255 respectively. Using these values
defected part of any leaf Fig-3(c) is extracted. The pixels have
HSV values in the declared range are masked and converted
into Black and White format Fig-3(d).

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

2) Decision Tree: Decision Tree is a major technique
used in data mining to classify large amounts of data and
extract data with similar patterns. Dataset is broken down into
smaller subsets addition to that decision tree is developed
resulting in a final result consisting of decision tree and leaf
nodes. Classification of large number of data and extracting
features having similar patterns using decision tree yields
extraordinary results

D. Feature extraction
Extracting characteristics of an image is known as feature
extraction. Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) is
used for extracting the feature set. GLCM is the statistical
method of exploring texture, which considers the spatial
bonding of pixels [20]. Each pixel map produces a cooccurrence matrix for the infected portion of the picture.
During creation of GLCMs, a set of offsets describing pixel
relations of different direction and distance is specified. Five
characteristics include contrast, dissimilarity, homogeneity,
second moment angularity, energy and correlation are
extracted in the suggested technique. Let
represents the

3) K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN): Similar and dissimilar
data are classified to more than one class using KNN
classification technique. N dimensional numeric attributes
are used to depict the train set. A point in N dimensional space
represents respective values in the dataset [21]. A KNN
classifier classifies the dataset by looking at the pattern in
training set that are closest to the unknown samples. How
close these samples are defined by Euclidean distance. By
making use of the features that were inherited in the feature
extraction step, the image is classified into a specific class.

( , ) entry in the normalized GLCM. N is equal to the
total number of distinct gray levels in the quantized image.
GLCM features like Energy, Contrast Features, Dissimilarity,
Homogeneity, ASM are extracted using (8-12)
Energy = ‚àë ,

(

(8)

)

Contrast Features =

( ‚àí )

(9)

4) Support Vector Machine (SVM): Support vector
machine algorithm finds a hyperplane that distinctly
classifies the data points. The hyperplane is an N-dimensional
space (the number of features -N) which helps to classify the
values. There are various methods to find a hyperplane in
order to separate two data points but we need to find an
optimal hyperplane which has a maximum margin (there
should be a maximum distance between two points of both
the classes). Maximizing the distance(margin) provides
reinforcement so that dataset can be classified with more
confidence percentage. SVM can be used to transform
features into much higher dimensions.

,

Dissimilarity =

| ‚àí |

(10)

,

,

=(

)

1+( ‚àí )

(11)
(12)

E. Classification
After feature extraction the next step is using the data and
classifying different types of diseases. Classification is the
process of grouping data based on similarities. Here
classification is used to classify the diseases that the leaves
are having. Machine learns how to identify the proper name
of a diseased leaf. Various types of models are available but
in this proposed methodology either of the following models
can be used and respective outcome can be achieved.

IV.

RESULTS

The dataset consists of different leaves having different
diseases like pepper bell and tomato with bacterial spot,
potato and tomato with early blight and late blight. It also
contains normal images of these leaves. Fig-4 shows the
original images of leaves followed by the segmented images
and black and white formatted images. The segmented
images are used for feature extraction. Five features are
extracted using GLCM and are stored in dataset. Total 8000
images were used for training the model and the testing set
contains overall of 100 images wherein 25 healthy images of
leaf and 25 images of each disease (Early Blight, Late Blight
and Bacterial spot) is present. The classification's efficiency
is evaluated by comparing the predicted type and original
type. In the proposed methodology, for classification
purposes the dataset was tested with Random Forest,
Decision Tree, KNN and SVM classifiers. Random Forest
proved to be yielding maximum accuracy of 98%. Table-2
represents the confusion matrix of random forest. Only One
of the leaves infected with bacterial spot was identified as
Late Blight and one of the leaves infected with Late Blight
was identified as Early Blight. Fig-6 represents the accuracy
of Random forest on all diseases. Other reliable approaches
are Decision Tree , KNN and SVM which yields acceptable
accuracies of 94%, 92%, 90% respectively. which are
reflected in Table-3,4,5 respectively in the form of confusion
matrix. Table-1 and Fig-5 reflects the result of all the

1) Random Forest: Random Forest is one of the efficient
machine learning classification method. Large number of
datasets can be classified using this technique. Random forest
is a group of decision trees, Where N training samples are
selected randomly and each tree is trained using these N
samples with replacement.
Random Forest pseudocode:
1. ‚ÄúK‚Äù features from ‚Äúm‚Äù are selected randomly.
(k<<m)
2. Using the best split point node ‚Äúd‚Äù is calculated
among the given ‚ÄúK‚Äù features
3. Using the best split, the daughter nodes are splitted.
4. Unless ‚ÄúI‚Äù number of nodes are reached repeat 1 to
3 steps
5. To create ‚Äún‚Äù number of trees, steps 1 to 4 are
repeated.

proposed approaches with respective accuracies. According
to the results it is proved that Random Forest classifier has
enhanced the plant disease detection process as compared to
approaches used in [22].

[11]

CONCLUSION

This paper presents different methodologies of
automated computerized disease detection in plants, which
can be done using image segmentation and classification
methods. The algorithms were tested on three diseases
namely Early Blight, Late Blight and Bacterial Spot.
Recognition of the diseases is the main purpose of the
proposed approach. HSV alteration method proved to be
very efficient for identifying the diseased part from the leaf,
adding to which GLCM also improved the accuracy by
extracting texture features. Hence by evaluating the results,
the proposed approach yields accurate detection of plant
leaf diseases with minimum computational complexity.

Abstract‚ÄîThe HPCC Systems Production Machine Learning
bundles provide a diverse set of features that allow the parallelized creation and training of Machine learning models and a
largesetofevaluationmetricsthatcanbeusedtotestthetrained
model to ascertain its performance. To help monitor the models
more closely however, a new set of evaluation methods that
incorporate the analysis of clusters and the selection of features,
aswellasothercommonlyusedtests,havebeenproposed,implemented, and tested. The implementations are written completely
inEnterpriseControlLanguageandsupportthevariousfeatures
provided by the Machine Learning bundles such as the Myriad
Interface. This paper provides a comprehensive summary of
the evaluation metrics currently available in the library, before
presenting the details of the design and implementation of the
new evaluation methods. It the goes on to present the results of
testing these implementations against implementations present
in the python scikit-learn library, and a few data visualisations
demonstratingsomeusesoftheimplementedevaluationmetrics.

learning models (clustering), and to add diversity in the
number of ways in which the models as well as the data
can be monitored (by providing feature selection methods,
for example). Some other popular evaluation metrics that are
often cited in literature are also included. A brief description
of the metrics that were implemented, and their design are
detailed in the paper. This is followed by the results of testing
for these implementations in various criteria such as features
and accuracy, and then by a few data visualisations that
demonstrate the use of these evaluation metrics.

Index Terms‚ÄîHPCC Systems, Machine Learning, Performance Evaluation Metrics

III. P ROPOSED M ETRICS

I. I NTRODUCTION
The HPCC Systems platform is an open source set of
features that provides high-performance, parallel processing
and delivery for big data applications. The platform provides
predictivemodelingfunctionalitiesthatcanbeusedtoperform
Machine Learning (ML) operations on Big data.
With regards to evaluation metrics, the supervised learning
bundles are quite diverse and feature rich. The KMeans and
NLPbundleshowever,havenoevaluationmethodstomonitor
trainedmodels.Anoverviewoftheexistingevaluationmetrics
present in different bundles is presented in the paper.
Keeping the existing metrics in mind, the main objective
while choosing a new set of evaluation metrics to implement
was to include methods for the analysis of unsupervised

¬ã,(((

II. S UMMARY OF E XISTING M ETRICS
An brief summary of the various evaluation metrics present
in the HPCC Systems Production ML Bundles, organized
bundle-wise, is presented in Table I.

The design of the metrics implemented, that help users
monitor models more closely, are presented here. They include intrinsic and extrinsic measures of the performance of
clustering models, tests that aid in feature selection, and a few
popular benchmarks that are commonly found in literature.
A. Balanced F-Score
The F-Score, is a statistical measure of a tests accuracy.
It is calculated as the weighted harmonic mean of the tests
precision and recall. When both the precision and the recall
are assigned equal weights, this score is called the balanced Fscore. An F-Score of 1 indicates perfect precision and recall.
An F-Score of 0 indicates the worst possible precision and
recall. The F score can provide a more realistic measure of a
tests performance by using both precision and recall.
1) Proposed Implementation: Since both the precision and
recall per class are readily available by the use of the AccuracyByClass measure present in the ML Core bundle, the Balanced F-Score may be directly implemented into this function

217

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

Algorithm 1 The addition of Balanced F-Score into the result
structure of AccuracyByClass function.
Input: pred : values predicted by the model
Input: actual : actual values
Output: F-Score per class, per classiÔ¨Åer, per work-item.
1: a ‚Üê AccuracyByClass(pred, actual)
2: prcsn ‚Üê a.precision
3: recll ‚Üê a.recall
4: f score ‚Üê 2 ‚àó prcsn ‚àó recll/(prcsn ‚àó recll)
5: return fscore

3: tot ‚Üê acc.totcnt (Total number of samples)
4: hamming loss ‚Üê err/tot
5: return hamming loss
C. Silhouette CoefÔ¨Åcient

within the transform that creates the result, by integrating the
balanced harmonic mean of the precision and the recall into
it. The process of obtaining the Balanced F-Score is detailed
in Algorithm 1.

Silhouette analysis is a way to measure a points closeness
to its own cluster as well as its separation from other clusters
[1]. It provides an easy way to Ô¨Ånd the optimum value for k
during k-means clustering [2].
Silhouette values lie in the range of (-1, 1). A value of +1
indicates that the sample point is far away from its neighboring
cluster and very close to the cluster it is assigned. Similarly, a
value of -1 indicates that the point is closer to its neighboring
cluster than to the cluster it is assigned.
1) Computation: The Silhouette score for each individual
sample is calculated as follows. If a is the average of the
distances of the sample from all other samples in its assigned
cluster, and b is the average of the distances of the sample
from all points assigned to the closest cluster to the sample,
not assigned to it (Here, the closest cluster is the one that
essentially produces the smallest b value). Once these values
are computed, the coefÔ¨Åcient is given by (1)
Si =

B. Hamming Loss
Hamming loss is a simple measure that is used to conveniently evaluate multi-label classiÔ¨Åcation models. It is given
by the fraction of labels that are incorrectly classiÔ¨Åed, among
all the labels.
a) Proposed implementation: Since the error count is
readily available in the Accuracy measure present in the
ML Core bundle, the Hamming Loss can be obtained as

bi ‚àí ai
max(bi , ai )

(1)

2) Proposed implementation: The proposed implementation takes as input the labels produced by the clustering
algorithm and the positions (co-ordinates / features) of the
samples. It returns the average silhouette coefÔ¨Åcient of all the
samples present per cluster, per work item. The implementation involves the creation of two variations. The Ô¨Årst variation
produces the silhouette score for each individual point, and the

218

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

second variation gives the average of these scores to produce
one score for all the points. The algorithm to produce the
Silhouette score per point is detailed in Algorithm 3.
Algorithm 3 Algorithm to produce Silhouette score for each
point
Input: labels : labels assigned to the points
Input: points : co-ordinates / features of the points
Output: Silhouette score per point, per work-item.
1: points ‚Üê JOIN samples, labels
2: Find ‚Äôa‚Äô values :

pairs ‚Üê All pairs of points in same cluster
{Pairs is the set of all ordered pairs of points
that belong to the same cluster}
4:
dist ‚Üê Distances between these pairs
5:
a ‚Üê Average(dist) per left point
6: Find ‚Äôb‚Äô values :
7:
pairs ‚Üê All pairs of points from different clusters
{Pairs is the set of all ordered pairs of points
that belong to the different clusters}
8:
dist ‚Üê Distances between these pairs
9:
clust ave ‚Üê Average(dist) per cluster, per left point
10:
b ‚Üê min(clust ave) among clusters, per left point
11: silhouette ‚Üê (b ‚àí a)/max(a, b)
12: return silhouette
D. Chi Squared Feature Selection Test
The Chi squared test is a statistical hypothesis test where
the sampling distribution assumes the form of a œá2 distribution
when the null hypothesis assumed is correct [3]. In the context
of feature selection, it may be used to establish the degree of
dependence of two categorical variables by analysing the null
hypothesis that they are independent of each other. Hence, it
can be used to determine whether a classiÔ¨Åer is dependent on a
certain feature. This test can only be used when both variables
are categorical.
1) Contingency Table: The contingency table represents the
number of samples present in the data for each combination
of sample category and feature category. To start with the chi2
test, a contingency table of the data is Ô¨Årst constructed.
2) Chi square value and Null hypothesis testing: In the
Chi squared test, we Ô¨Årst assume the null hypothesis that the
two variables are independent. We then proceed to construct
a contingency table that supports this claim, based off of the
sums of rows and columns of our existing contingency table
[4]. We then calculate the chi square value from (2)
 (ei ‚àí oi )2
œá2 =
(2)
ei
i
For a large population, the probability distribution of this value
for a random sampling (small subset) of the population is
known to approximately follow a œá2 distribution, and hence
the name of the coefÔ¨Åcient. A large value of œá2 indicates that
it is less probable that the sample is not an outlier and is a
good representation of the population.

Hence, when the null hypothesis that the sample is independent of a feature produces a large œá2 value, it indicates
that there is a low probability that the null hypothesis is true
and hence null hypothesis is rejected and the dependence of
the two variables is established. A lower œá2 value indicates
that it is more probable that the null hypothesis is true. It
is not known for certain, however the null hypothesis cannot
be rejected and the dependence of the variables cannot be
established.
3) Proposed implementation: The implementation consists
of two separate functionalities. The Ô¨Årst part creates a contingency table of the data, and the second Ô¨Ånds the chi2 values.
a) Contingency table: The contingency table function
takes two different DiscreteField datasets and returns a contingency table for each combination of feature and classiÔ¨Åer,
per work item. Though a contingency table can be formed
between any two categorical variables, the function names its
parameters features and samples for convenience.
Algorithm 4 Algorithm to produce contingency table
Input: features : Independent data
Input: samples : Dependent data
Output: Contingency table per combination of classiÔ¨Åer and
feature, per work-item
1: comb ‚Üê JOIN samples, f eatures
2: grouped ‚Üê GROUP comb by samples, features
3: contingency ‚Üê COUNT grouped per group
4: return contingency
b) Chi Squared Test: The chi squared feature test implementation takes the independent (features) and dependent
(samples) data as parameters, and returns the chi squared
coefÔ¨Åcient value and the number of degrees of freedom for
each combination of classiÔ¨Åer and feature.
Equation (2) is used to calculate the chi square coefÔ¨Åcient
value from the expected and actual values, in Line 16 of
Algorithm 5.
Equation (3) is used to compute the entries of the expected
contingency table mentioned at Line 9 of Algorithm 5.

E. Adjusted Rand Index
The rand index in data clustering is a statistical measure of
similarity between two data clustering result [5] [6]. The rand
index however, does not necessarily produce a lower score
for a random labelling of data. The Adjusted Rand Index is
the corrected-for-chance version of the rand index, that uses
the expected rand index value to correct the score. Adjusted
Rand Index can assume values between -1 and 1. A value of

219

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

Algorithm 5 Algorithm to perform Chi squared feature selection test
Input: features : Independent data
Input: samples : Dependent data
Output: Chi Squared value and P - value per combination of
classiÔ¨Åer and feature, per work-item
1: cont ‚Üê Contingency(samples, f eatures)
2: f group ‚Üê GROUP cont by feature
3: f sums ‚Üê SUM(f group) per group
4: s group ‚Üê GROUP cont by classiÔ¨Åer
5: s sums ‚Üê SUM(f group) per group
6: all group ‚Üê GROUP cont by feature and classiÔ¨Åer
7: all sums ‚Üê SUM(all group) per group
8: et ‚Üê Expected contingency table using f sums, s sums,
all sum
9: rows group ‚Üê GROUP cont per feature
10: rows ‚Üê COUNT rows group per group
11: cols group ‚Üê GROUP cont per classiÔ¨Åer
12: cols ‚Üê COUNT cols group per group
13: dof ‚Üê (rows ‚àí 1) ‚àó (cols ‚àí 1)
14: œá2 ‚Üê (cont ‚àí et)2 /et2
15: p ‚Üê cdf (œá2 , dof )
16: return (œá2 , p)

1 indicates perfectly matching clustering results, and a lower
value indicates mismatched clustering results.
As an evaluation metric, the Adjusted Rand Index may be
used to compare the values produced by a clustering algorithm
to the actual values (ground truth), making ARI an extrinsic
evaluation method.
1) Computation: The Adjusted Rand Index is calculated
from the contingency table of the data as shown in (5), where
nij is the element on the ith row and j th column, ai is the
sum of the ith row, bj is the sum of the j th column, and n is
the number of samples.

2) Proposed Implementation: The implementation takes as
parameters the two different labelling / clustering results, and
returns the Adjusted Rand Score per work-item. It involves
Ô¨Ånding the required sums from the contingency table of the
data and combining them to form the ARI as per (5). The
algorithm to Ô¨Ånd the ARI from the contingency table of the
data is detailed in Algorithm 6.
F. Area Under Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve
The Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) Curve is a
graphical plot that indicates the ability of a binary classiÔ¨Åer
to differentiate between two classes [7]. The curve is created
by plotting the True Positive Rate (TPR) vs the False Positive
Rate (FPR) of the classiÔ¨Åer its threshold is varied from 0 to 1.
(When a classiÔ¨Åer produces scores indicating the probability
that a sample belongs to a particular class, the probability

sums
7: col C2 ‚Üê
cont2
8: all C2 ‚Üê
2
9: nij ‚Üê SUM(all C2)
SU M (cont)
10: nC2 ‚Üê
2
11: a ‚Üê SUM(row C2)
12: b ‚Üê SUM(col C2)
13: ari ‚Üê (nij ‚àí a ‚àó b/n)/(0.5(a + b) ‚àí a ‚àó b/n)
14: return ari

threshold is the probability above which a sample must be
scored so that the sample is classiÔ¨Åed as positive.)
The Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC) is a measure of
the classiÔ¨Åer‚Äôs ability to distinguish between classes. When
using normalized units, this area is also numerically equal to
the probability that a random positive sample is scored higher
than a random negative sample [8].
The AUC is an evaluation measure for binomial classiÔ¨Åcation. It can, however, be extended to evaluate multi-class
classiÔ¨Åers, by evaluating them in a one vs. all fashion or a
one vs. one fashion.
1) Proposed Implementation: The implementation takes as
parameters the actual labels of the dependent data and the
predicted scores (per point, per class) produced by the classiÔ¨Åer. The implementation supports multi-class classiÔ¨Åcation
by arranging the classes in a one vs. all fashion. The AUC is
obtained as the probability that a random positive sample is
scored higher than a random negative sample. The algorithm
to obtain the AUC from the data provided is detailed in
Algorithm 7.
IV. T ESTING
To test the evaluation metrics implemented, the results of
these functions were compared with the results produced by
their corresponding implementations in the popular python
machine learning library, Scikit-Learn [9]. The tests include
various criteria such as multiple work-item, multiple classiÔ¨Åers, etc. To conduct the tests, randomised data was generated
and fed to both implementations1 . Testing indicates that the
results produced by this implementation matches those produced by sklearn to a high degree of precision. The results of
these tests are presented here.

220

1 The

sklearn functions were called using a python embedding in ECL

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

Algorithm 7 Algorithm to obtain AUC from the actual labels
and the predicted scores
Input: actual : Actual labels
Input: pred : Predicted scores per sample, per class
Output: AUC per class, per classiÔ¨Åer, per work-item
1: comb ‚Üê JOIN actual, pred with same id, classiÔ¨Åer, class
WHERE isT rue ‚Üê true IF class = actualclass
2: pairs ‚Üê JOIN comb, comb with same classiÔ¨Åer, class
WHERE lef t.isT rue = true and right.isT rue = false
WHERE
IF lef t.score > right.score:
pairs.score ‚Üê 1.0
ELSE IF lef t.score = right.score:
pairs.score ‚Üê 0.5
ELSE:
pairs.score ‚Üê 0.0
3: auc ‚Üê AVERAGE(pairs.score) per class, per classiÔ¨Åer
4: return auc

B. Adjusted Rand Index
The test produces two sets of 1000 random labelling per
work-item, for 10 work-items. These two sets of labels are
used as input for ARI. Test results are presented in Table III.
It is seen that the ARI values are close to 0, as is characteristic
of ARI for random labelling.
C. Area Under ROC Curve
The test produces 1000 samples with 3 different classiÔ¨Åers
and 4 different classes, per work-item for 2 work-items. Test
results are displayed in Table IV. It is seen that the AUC values
are close to 0.5, as expected of a random classiÔ¨Åcation.

The test produces a dependent (classiÔ¨Åer) variable set of
1000 samples with 3 classiÔ¨Åers and 4 classes per work-item,
for 2 work-items, and a similar independent (feature) variable

V. V ISUALISATIONS
To demonstrate the use of these evaluation metrics, a few
data visualisations performed on the results of analysis of real
world datasets are presented.
A. Silhouette score
The Silhouette score can be used to Ô¨Ånd the inherent quality
of the clustering results without the use of ground truth values.
Hence, the score can be used to Ô¨Ånd the optimal value of K
in K-Means clustering by selecting the model which has the
highest average silhouette score. Fig. 1 shows the silhouette
score of the clustering result as the K value changes from K=2
to K=5.

B. Area Under Curve
The area under the curve can be used to study the performance of a classiÔ¨Åcation model. The chart in Fig. 2 shows the
variation in AUC as the number of training samples increases.

Machine Learning Bundles were successfully implemented
and tested. These metrics can help users monitor their Machine learning models better and can help tweak their hyperparameters. The implementations also support the various
features of the production ML bundles such as the Myriad
interface.
R EFERENCES

C. Adjusted Rand Index
The Adjusted Rand Index (ARI) may be used to compare
different clustering models by comparing their results, and
to compare results with the ground truth labels to check the
accuracy of the result. The visualisation in Fig. 3 shows the
comparison of the ground truth with models of differing K
values in K-Means clustering.
VI. C ONCLUSION
The six evaluation metrics for machine learning models
chosen for implementation for the HPCC Systems Production

HPEHGGHG2FWDYHRQELJGDWDSODWIRUPOLNH+3&&6\VWHPV
7KLV SDSHU GLVFXVVHV RQH VXFK DSSOLFDWLRQ RI FRQWUROOLQJ
WUDIILFOLJKWVGXUDWLRQXVLQJIX]]\ORJLFSDFNDJHRI2FWDYH

Abstract‚Äî HPCC Systems is an open source big data
processing platform used to provide big data solutions. Big
data processing applications such as image processing, audio
processing often make use of mathematical computations,
however currently there is little provision for execution of
extensive mathematical computations on HPCC systems
platform. Gnu Octave is an opensource programming
language for numerical computations, to enable HPCC
Systems to use the power of Octave this paper proposes design
and implementation of an Octave plugin. Octave plugin gives
HPCC Systems a new dimension for its mathematical
computation ability, especially the simplicity of Octave
enhances its numerical computation power. The Octave
plugin is implemented and tested by executing an use case of
fuzzy inference system for traffic control. The results
demonstrate the successful integration of Octave plugin with
HPCC Systems.

2019 4th International Conference on Computational Systems and Information Technology for Sustainable Solution (CSITSS)

(YDOXDWLQJGHHSOHDUQLQJEDVHGPRGHOVIRU
SUHGLFWLQJFOLFNWKURXJKUDWH
Gautam Chauhan
'HSWRI,QIRUPDWLRQ6FLHQFHDQG
(QJLQHHULQJ
&05,QVWLWXWHRI7HFKQRORJ\
%HQJDOXUX,QGLD
JDXWDPFKDXKDQ#JPDLOFRP

Dhruva Vatsa Mishra
'HSWRI,QIRUPDWLRQ6FLHQFHDQG
(QJLQHHULQJ
&05,QVWLWXWHRI7HFKQRORJ\
%HQJDOXUX,QGLD
GYPPLVKUD#JPDLOFRP

Abstract‚ÄîDeep neural networks are finding their way into most
of the fields in today‚Äôs world. One such field is predicting the
click through rate for online advertising. Multiple deep neural
network based models for click through rate prediction have
been proposed in the last few years. Model assessment is crucial
in solving any real world problem. With this paper, we shed
some light on the recent deep learning models which have been
outperforming traditional models lately. Two benchmark
datasets were used: namely Criteo and Avazu dataset.
Comprehensive experiments were conducted to demonstrate the
superiority of some of the models over others. Most studies
include pre-setting the hyper parameters for optimum
performance. In this study, the models learn the hyper
parameters to further improve the results and maximize the
predictive accuracy. Key findings include how inclusion of
feature dependency in the model can be beneficial when data
present has higher number of features. Factors influencing
model selection such as no pre-training or feature engineering
required might not be the best options when aiming for
performance. Finally, this study concludes how hyper
parameters affect chosen deep model‚Äôs performance.

II. LITERATURE SURVEY

factorization machines, recommender systems

'HSDUWPHQWRI&6 (

0\VXUX,QGLD
YLMLODNVKPLKF#VMFHDFLQ

Abstract‚ÄîAs Internet technology has become a part of the
lifestyle of the common man, research efforts are extensively
made in the fields of Natural Language Processing (NLP) and
Information Retrieval. Studying regional languages for
developing the system to store, retrieve, extract the
information from the database has gained lots of prominence
nowadays. Case studies show that Ontological Information
Retrieval has many advantages over keyword-based approach.
In this paper we have focused on the general architecture of
ontology-based Information Retrieval used for Kannada.

,, /,7(5$785(6859(<$1'5(/$7(':25.

Keywords- Ontology, Information Retrieval, Kannada, NLP

DLVKZDU\DVHWKFV#UYFHHGXLQ

7KHDUFKLWHFWXUHGLDJUDPLVVKRZQLQ)LJXUH

Abstract‚Äî Classification and in-depth analysis of these
various forms of distraction can allow for intelligent alert
systems. Before creating an artificial intelligence system, it is
imperative to understand the various parameters that are
interplaying in the current environment. Based on how these
factors influence the behavior of a driver, the corrective
measures should be suggested to the driver. (At later stages,
such changes may be incorporated into the vehicle itself.)

,

'U6RZP\DUDQL&1
&RPSXWHU6FLHQFH'HSDUWPHQW
59&ROOHJHRI(QJLQHHULQJ
%HQJDOXUX,QGLD
VRZP\DUDQLFQ#UYFHHGXLQ

,1752'8&7,21

'ULYHUVGXULQJORQJMRXUQH\VRUGXULQJVORZPRYLQJWUDIILF
